posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked:
Our shooterRotation subsytem basically had 4 modes or states: Speaker Tracking, Intake, Amp Score, and Climbing.

I am attempting to figure out ways to take our programming up a level in the future.  This year we just used boolean variables to keep tract of what state it was in and wrote methods that set all of them to false except the mode we wanted to enter.

Obviously each of these states was a different angle we wanted to set the shooter rotation to with speaker tracking being an angle that was calculated by our vision subsystem.  So we just wrote some if logic based on the state of the booleans in the period function of the subsystem to set these angles.

As I look at many teams codes I see that many seem to be using Enum’s to create these states and so some things with them.  I have done some basic googling on them, but not really following how to implement them or if this is the best way to go about controlling the state of a subsystem.

I feel like this could be applied to LED subsystems pretty easily too and maybe help streamline some of the programing of these to avoid

So are Enums the best way to achieve this?  If so can someone help me with some explanations and code examples?  If not what is the best way to achieve this?

For a set of mutually exclusive states, like those four modes you described, enums are the way to go.

Inside the class, just reassign the value of the variable to change state. Getters and setters can facilitate access by other classes. To act on state in a periodic method when using an enum, a switch statement is usually cleaner than an if-else-if statement:

That way your periodic could look like shooterState.setShooterAngle() and not even have a switch statement

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked: Ok so not gonna lie I am a little bit lost on what is going on here in this.  I am not a programmer by trade and have been learning as I go over the last few years so this shot a little over my head.

Implementing this using commands may be something to consider as well. Because only one command can be running on a subsystem at a time, they essentially act as a state machine like some of the ones you have here. Commands are fairly easy to implement if you have experience with them and streamline the state machine process significantly.

A simple method for this is having a command for each mode that you want the shooter to be in. You can schedule these commands based on what buttons the operator is pressing or other criteria. So long as each of these commands “requires” the subsystem, only one of these commands can be running at any given time. Then, you simply set the shooter angle in each command according to what you want the command to do.

The command-based method is also very useful because you can set default commands, which are just commands that always run when no other command that requires the subsystem it is linked to is scheduled. I’d highly recommend looking into some documentation and some examples of command-based programming for FRC .

This sequence of articles serves as an introduction to and reference for the WPILib command-based framework. For a collection of example projects using the command-based framework, see Command-Base...

link_counts.title: Command-Based Programming — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked:
I would also probably need a disabled state that it would be sent to anytime the robot got disabled and that state would get its target angle from whatever its current angle was… This would allow the shooter to be in that diabled state until some command put it into another state???  And robot disabled could set the state to disabled?

You are correct though we would want a state for it to start in so it didnt move on enabled for safety reasons.

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked:
We use the command framework and are familar with it.  I guess it seemed like alot of commands that didnt do much other than change an angle.

An LED sybsystem would be a ton of simple commands not necessarily changed by button presses.  So you would have to create a bunch of sequential command groups rather than just having say the IntakeNote command change the state with a single line of code.  I could be wrong here and missing something though as well…

Maybe I am just looking for a solution that already exists, but I guess that is why I am asking the questions.

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked: Just wanted to chime in here that learning to store complex data in enums was a game changer for the cleanliness of our code… I just learned here though that I could add methods here as in @Jus example…

Commands that don’t do much than change an angle aren’t a bad thing. Commands can be as simple or as complex as you want them to be. We have some commands that just flip a boolean.

With your example of the LED subsystem, there could just be a single command that is always running and has logic inside of it that changes the LED state based on parameters from the other subsystems. Commands can have a lot of logic or just do singular things, as long as you string them together properly.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Striving for a command to be a single state and making the command not rely on history or parameters is ideal for usability. How many different versions of essentially the same code is best before using parameters? Hard to say and there are CD threads discussing that. We had six colors and rainbow in seven one-line methods. It was very easy to code, use, and understand by the whole team.

I don’t regret the “bloat” of a dozen extra lines of code if we can accurately, perfectly, correctly use the correct command in an instant in emergency changes between matches. Similarly it was easy to use at home while developing robot motions. This is “mistake-proofing” and it works.

In the LED subsystem:

[Having a color command call an identically named non-command may be too redundant and could be subject to refactoring next season. The false is blink option.

Also, the students got so enthralled with lambda expressions (new to them) they often recoded the runOnce lambda instead of using the already coded command; more refactoring.

We do use parameters, in part, for the flywheel speeds and sometimes a dedicated method for a single speed. More refactoring to achieve consistency.]

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked:
If I were only using it for the values, it certainly would be just as easy to use a constant like that, however, I was using this for other purposes also.

Example: Setting a “current tracking target” of like “Targets.SPEAKER”, then I can programmatically take action based on that enum value also…

here is some examples of things that are easier when using as an enum…

Overall, it helps me organize things for better code re-readability and re-use.  Putting complex data in constants can work, but then you would still need to track which value you have to know which constant to ask for, and write code to properly select the proper constant. All that is handled by using an enum…
